node.title: FunctionValuePostprocessor to printout the values read by PiecewiseMultilinear
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
All,
I am using FunctionValuePostprocessor in Postprocessors to printout the values of a file read by PiecewiseMultilinear in Functions but it is seemingly not working (I got just zeros).
Please help. S.Thomas
Did you check the execute_on parameter? Is it being executed often enough?

Thank you, GiudGiud!
I set as
execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'

The file read by PiecewiseMultilinear in Functions has a form of
AXIS Y
xxx xxx xxx .... xxx
AXIS T
yyy yyy yyy ... yyy
DATA
zzz zzz zzz ... zzz
.
.
zzz zzz zzz ... zzz
So, we may have to sum the values in DATA for AXIS Y at each time step?
FunctionElementIntegral may help?

the FunctionValuePP is only computing one value of the function, at the origin (x=0, y=0, z=0) by default
if you want an integral then I agree FunctionElementIntegral does it

node.title: Request for Assistance with `free(): invalid next size (fast)` Error in Material Class
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am encountering a free(): invalid next size (fast) error in one of my material classes within the Moose application.
The function computeQpStress() successfully executes for each of the 8 _qps, which I verified using the VSCode GDB debugger.  Afterwards, computeQpStress() executes successfully again for all 8 _qps.The output up to that point looks like this:
Time Step 1, time = 5e-06, dt = 5e-06  
Currently Executing  
    Computing Pre-SMO Residual  
      Computing Residual                                                                 [ 24.14 s] [  208 MB]  
Pre-SMO residual: 8e-08  
 Skipping predictor this step  
    Finished Computing Pre-SMO Residual                                                  [ 24.14 s] [  208 MB]  
    Computing Residual.....                                                              [ 39.61 s] [  208 MB]  

However, the issue arises when the code reaches the following section in NonlinearSystem.C (located at /framework/src/systems/NonlinearSystem.C, lines 190–197):
if (time_integrator_solve)  
  mooseAssert(_time_integrators.size() == 1,  
              "If solve is overridden, then there must be only one time integrator");  

if (time_integrator_solve)  
  _time_integrators.front()->solve();  
else  
  system().solve();  
The moment the code executes system().solve();, the application crashes with the following error:
free(): invalid next size (fast) error  

Single stepping until exit from function libmesh_petsc_snes_residual,  
which has no line number information.  
Single stepping until exit from function SNESComputeFunction,  
which has no line number information.  
Single stepping until exit from function SNESSolve_NEWTONLS,  
which has no line number information.  

Thread 1 "rhocp-dbg" received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.  
__pthread_kill_implementation (no_tid=0, signo=6, threadid=<optimized out>) at ./nptl/pthread_kill.c:44  

Notably, other material classes in my Moose application are functioning correctly, and I’m unable to pinpoint the root cause of this issue.
I would greatly appreciate your guidance on troubleshooting and resolving this problem.
Thank you for your help!
Best regards,
Vikram Roy

Hello
If you are already running this using a debugger, can you print a backtrace? You use a breakpoint on the error (if you're lucky b MPI_Abort should suffice), then the execution stops there and you can use bt to get a full backtrace.
You ll want to compile in debug mode to get the line number

Is it stateful? Does it use old and older values of material properties?
if so try setting snesmf_reuse_base=false in the executioner. It's just a hunch

are these old variable values?
  std::copy(_state_var_old[_qp].begin(), _state_var_old[_qp].end(), _state_var[_qp].begin());
These are old state variables
Make sure the current properties are sized correctly before copying.  std::copy does not allocate space.

node.title: How to solve thermal expansion problems with tens (or hundreds) of gas gap?
node.bodyText:
This geometry always appears in the solid nuclear reactor core: cylinder and hollow cylinders with the same axial line - rod, gas gap, clad, shown in this figure(top view):

I want to solve the thermal expansion for this problem.

A natural thought is to only model rod and clad mesh. The mesh volumes remain void on the gas gap position. I use HeatConduction and HeatSource Kernels, [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]. The temperature on the outer side of the rod or inner side of the clad is got from GapHeatTransfer. This method will be feasible for only one channel in this picture. But for tens or hundreds channels? It will cost lots of time which is unacceptable.
Another thought is to use different domains for Heat Conduction Module and Solid Mechanics Module: For Heat Conduction Module - rod, gas gap, clad; For Solid Mechanics Module:  rod, clad. But in this method, I encounter an error about negative Jacobian

This method I cannot know the way to achieve it. Omit the gas gap for both rod and clad. In the Heat Conduction Module, try to make the temperature abrupt change to represent the thermal resistance caused by gas gap. In the Solid Mechanics Module, the displacement for the rod block and clad block is the same based on the assumption. However, I cannot find the way to achieve this....
So what's your suggestions? Do you know how to solve thermal expansion problems with tens (or hundreds) of gas gap, or find ways to achieve 3)?

hello
this is likely covered in the BISON manual, which is available online
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/bison/
BISON is an application dedicated to these applications. I would recommend you ask for access here https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/Login It might take a while to get access considering your current affiliation

node.title: Errors about theory resolutions for thermal expansion...
node.bodyText:
Let's consider a problem about thermal expansion. A 2D circle plate with its center fixed are heated to 500 K. Its zero expansion temperature is 300 K. Its  thermal expansion coefficient is 2E-5 K^-1. Its radius is 50e-3 m. These conditions above are shown in the following figure:

And the govern equations and boundary conditions are:

Evidently, the theory solution for this problem is

So I want to use this solution to examine MOOSE. So I edit this input file:
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  [accg]
    type = AdvancedConcentricCircleGenerator
    ring_radii = '50.0e-3'
    ring_intervals = '200'
    ring_block_ids = '15 20'
    ring_block_names = 'inner_tri inner'
    external_boundary_id = 100
    external_boundary_name = 'right'
    num_sectors = 200
  []
  [name_dian1]
    type = BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator
    input = accg
    bottom_left = '${fparse 0.0-0.000000001} ${fparse 0.0-0.000000001} ${fparse 0.0-0.000000001}'
    top_right = '${fparse 0.0+0.000000001} ${fparse 0.0+0.000000001} ${fparse 0.0+0.000000001}'
    new_boundary = 'fix_point'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor_steel]
    youngs_modulus = 210e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.28
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  [../]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
  [expansion_steel_3]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    stress_free_temperature = 300.0
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 2.0e-5
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = thermal
  []
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    eigenstrain_names = thermal
    generate_output = 'vonmises_stress stress_xx strain_xx'
    strain = FINITE
    temperature = temp
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [temp]
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [changshu_wendu]
    type = ConstantAux
    variable = temp
    value = 500.0
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]


[BCs]
  [guding_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'fix_point'
    value = 0.0
  []
  [guding_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'fix_point'
    value = 0.0
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [max_disp_x]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = disp_x
  []
  [max_disp_y]
    type = NodalMaxValue
    variable = disp_y
  []
  [max_stress_xx]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = stress_xx
  []
  [max_strain_xx]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = strain_xx
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]


In theory, the max_disp_x and max_disp_y will be αΔTR = (2e-5 × 200 × 50e-3) m = 2e-4 m
the max_stress_xx will be very close to 0 Pa
the max_strain_xx will be αΔT =  2e-5 × 200 = 4e-3

The results diverge with the theory too much except the stress (close to 0) ! Could you tell me the reason? It seems that some error imported in the simulation I do not realize....

Hello
You have to set a poisson ratio of 0 to retrieve this analytical solution. Otherwise, you are seeing additional expansion from Poisson's effect.
Guillaume
You're right sir! But I'm still puzzled... It seems that in analytical solution, the Possions ratio cannot affect the final result... Why the solution from MOOSE is depended on the Possions ratio?

It seems that in analytical solution, the Possions ratio cannot affect the final result

in your derivation you ignored the poisson ratio. you only looked at diagonal components of the stress tensor.

node.title: understanding MultiApps and Transfers Systems.
node.bodyText:
hi all,
i am trying to understand how to set up a coupled problem in MOOSE. for this, i used one of the tutorials in Combined module in MOOSE, and set up the same problem using MultiApps and Transfers.
the main app is solving for displacements, and sub app is solving for temperature. temperature is passed to the main app at the beginning of each timestep.
i getting a difference of values for the temperature using both the above-mentioned methods. also, i have imposed an initial condition of T = 300 in both the methods, but it is not reflected in the postprocesser results.

can anyone please let me know if the problem is set up correctly in both the methods. i am doing this as an exercise to better understand how to set up coupled problems.
thanks.
following is the input file using combined module:

# https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/combined/tutorials/introduction/thermoech_step01.html
#

Hello
The problem is that you have set this up for loose coupling using MutlAipps + Transfer, so the equations are solved one after the other but never iterated within a time step.
You need to add fixed point parameters:
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  end_time = 5
  dt = 1

  fixed_point_max_its = 20
[]

see the fixed point parameters on this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Transient.html
and some discussions on fixed point here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Executioner/FixedPointAlgorithms/index.html

hi, i added the fixed point parameters, but i am still seeing the same results as earlier.

  dt        = 1
  end_time  = 5

  fixed_point_min_its = 1
  fixed_point_max_its = 20
  fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-10
  fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-12

  fixed_point_algorithm   = picard

  nl_rel_tol  = 1e-10
  nl_abs_tol  = 1e-12
[]

how can i ensure that the main file is taking temperature value from the sub file for every fixed point iteration? is there any such option available in the Debug system?
another thing i tried is setting
[Problem]
  solve = false
[]

in the sub file where temperature is solved. the main app then reports same value of temperature for each timestep.
when i set the same option in the main file, the values are the same when i was solving both files. does this mean that the coupling is in fact not occuring, and just the main app is being solved?

how can i ensure that the main file is taking temperature value from the sub file for every fixed point iteration?

You need to be transferring it. Using an object from the Transfers system, for example this one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppGeneralFieldShapeEvaluationTransfer.html
but you already do
[Transfers]
  [pass_temp_to_main]
    type            = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    source_variable = T
    variable        = T
    from_multi_app  = thermal
    execute_on      = 'TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]


is there any such option available in the Debug system?

you can use the regular exodus output in both the sub app and the main to check that the field is being passed

the main app then reports same value of temperature for each timestep.

that is totally normal if you are no longer solving the subapp problem

when i set the same option in the main file, the values are the same when i was solving both files

This does not seem right. If you set solve = false in the main app, the temperature from the subapp may be updated but there is no longer any solve in the main app.

does this mean that the coupling is in fact not occuring, and just the main app is being solved?

The coupling is occuring only in one direction right now, because you only have 1 transfer from the subapp to the main app. If there is to be feedback from the main app into the subapp solve, you need to be transferring the relevant field(s) from the main app to the sub app

hi, i have run the above problem once again using MultiApps and Transfers systems. what i am observing is that the eigenstrain, in this case the thermal strain, is getting computed for every time step, but it is not getting added to the total strain, because of which both total strain and the stress are reported to be zero at each timestep. what changes are to be made in the input file so that the eigenstrain is added to the total strain?

in your main app, you need to give the ComputeFiniteStrain the name of all the eigenstrains you want to use, with the eigenstrain_names parameter.
see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ADComputeFiniteStrain.html

hi, i already did that and its giving an error. i mentioned it in earlier reply.
when i add the command eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain in the ComputeFiniteStrain block, it shows me an error:
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Fixed point convergence reason: DIVERGED_NONLINEAR
Aborting as solve did not converge


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the TimeStepper 'ConstantDT' of type ConstantDT.

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

This is not an error from the incompatibility of the strain / eigen strain
This is non convergence. It could be a preconditioning issue, it could be from the executioner parameters
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
why is it so that this error shows after the command eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain is added in the ComputeFiniteStrain block?

Because the simulation is no longer converging.
Something about the setup could be wrong elsewhere, or simply the solver cannot solve the problem without modifications to the preconditioning

node.title: compute the sintered necks
node.bodyText: Hello, dear moose community. I would like to ask how do you count the sintered necks of particles in moose? This problem has been bothering me for a long time, and there has been no good solution. I look forward to your help.

Hello
It s possible but if you have to ask how it's likely that it will be too much trouble.
I would rather you update the app. Which app is it?
These errors are trivial to deal with:

some material properties should be stored as const references so modify the header appropriately
the constructor only takes a single argument now, the InputParameters
the format of the validParams has changed. See previous posts for how to deal with that

node.title: Solution without any constraint along Z-direction
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am having a weird observation and was hoping to get some insight from the community. I am showing a simplified version of the problem as an example here.
So, I have a quarter cylinder geometry for which I am solving the thermo-elastic problem under a certain temperature field. The boundary conditions are such that the face normal to global X-axis has Ux=0, Y-axis has Uy=0, and Z-axis has Uz=0. This is well constrained problem and the solution looks like below:

The corresponding moose_input file looks like so:
[Mesh]
  [fmg]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = input_geometry.e
  []
[]
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Functions]
  [./temp_function]
    type  = ParsedFunction
    value = '200.0*(z+0)'
  [../]
[]
[BCs]
  [face_fix_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = fix_y
    value = 0
  []
  [face_fix_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = fix_x
    value = 0
  []
  [face_fix_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = fix_z
    value = 0
  []
[]
[Modules]
  [TensorMechanics]
    [Master/All]
      strain = small
      incremental = False
      add_variables = True
      temperature = temp
      eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain
      generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz'
      use_automatic_differentiation = False
    []
  []
[]
[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor_core]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 150.0e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 1
  []
  [elasticity_tensor_skin]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 150.0e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    block = 2
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
  [thermal_expansion_strain_core]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 1.0e-4
    stress_free_temperature = 100.0
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
    block = 1
  []
  [thermal_expansion_strain_skin]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 1.0e-4
    stress_free_temperature = 100.0
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
    block = 2
  []
[]
[AuxVariables]
  [temp]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  []
  [stress_rr_core]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_tt_core]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_zz_core]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_rr_skin]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_tt_skin]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [stress_zz_skin]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [eigenstrain_yy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [eigenstrain_xx]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
  [eigenstrain_zz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]
[AuxKernels]
  [set_temp]
    variable = temp
    type = FunctionAux
    function = temp_function
  []
  [stress_zz_core]
    type = CylindricalRankTwoAux
    variable = stress_zz_core
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_j = 2
    index_i = 2
    center_point = '0 0 0'
    block = 1
  []
  [stress_rr_core]
    type = CylindricalRankTwoAux
    variable = stress_rr_core
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_j = 0
    index_i = 0
    center_point = '0 0 0'
    block = 1
  []
  [stress_tt_core]
    type = CylindricalRankTwoAux
    variable = stress_tt_core
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_j = 1
    index_i = 1
    center_point = '0 0 0'
    block = 1
  []
  [stress_zz_skin]
    type = CylindricalRankTwoAux
    variable = stress_zz_skin
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_j = 2
    index_i = 2
    center_point = '0 0 0'
    block = 2
  []
  [stress_rr_skin]
    type = CylindricalRankTwoAux
    variable = stress_rr_skin
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_j = 0
    index_i = 0
    center_point = '0 0 0'
    block = 2
  []
  [stress_tt_skin]
    type = CylindricalRankTwoAux
    variable = stress_tt_skin
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_j = 1
    index_i = 1
    center_point = '0 0 0'
    block = 2
  []
  [eigenstrain_yy]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = eigenstrain
    variable = eigenstrain_yy
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 1
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [eigenstrain_xx]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = eigenstrain
    variable = eigenstrain_xx
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [eigenstrain_zz]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = eigenstrain
    variable = eigenstrain_zz
    index_i = 2
    index_j = 2
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]
[Postprocessors]
  [temperature]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = temp
  []
  [sigma_xx]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = stress_xx
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [sigma_yy]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = stress_yy
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [sigma_zz]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = stress_zz
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [eigenstrain_xx]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = eigenstrain_xx
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [eigenstrain_yy]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = eigenstrain_yy
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [eigenstrain_zz]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = eigenstrain_zz
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]
[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = Newton
  start_time = 0.0
  dt = 0.1
  dtmax = 1.0
  dtmin = 0.001
  nl_abs_tol = 4e-07
  end_time = 1.0
  l_tol = 1e-5
[]
[Outputs]
  print_linear_residuals = true
  perf_graph = true
  csv = true
  [out]
    type = Exodus
    elemental_as_nodal = true
  []
  [console]
    type = Console
    max_rows = 100
  []
[]


Now the problem is if I change the Z-constraint to a single point: basically fix the origin [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] to Uz=0, the simulation no longer converge, which I believe is due to high stress generation at the constrained node.
However, if I impose no Uz constraints and only impose constraints in Ux and Uy, the simulation still runs giving a symmetric solution in stress which looks like below:

Now, my question is for the latter simulation where I did not impose any constraint along Z-axis how does MOOSE handle rigid body translation ?
And is there some numerical strategy which allows to solve for point constraint as boundary condition ?
Thanks,
Aritra

Now, my question is for the latter simulation where I did not impose any constraint along Z-axis how does MOOSE handle rigid body translation ?

MOOSE does not handle it in any special way unless you add parameters to PETSc to remove the null space. (not the recommended solution, the recommended solution is to have the right constraints on the system to prevent RBM)
Without that, you are getting whatever the nonlinear solver returned, which may include rigid body motion, and which likely depends on the preconditioning method used and the number of solve iterations.

Thanks, so to prevent RBM when I impose a single point/node constraint are there suggested numerical strategies that would help in convergence ? Since the problem I am trying to mimic in MOOSE imposes a single node constraint along Uz=0, but is solved without any convergence issues in commercial software.

is the linear solve diverging? You did not set petsc options so you are using the default preconditioning (ilu)
or is it the nonlinear solve?
The linear residual seem to get stuck at a fixed value, and yeah I did not set any petsc options.

try setting
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'

damn! it solved!!
what's the magic recipe :D ?
